posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
A new version of the Signal Server released today has a large commit concerning Key Transparency:

github.com/signalapp/Signal-Server

Key transparency `search` and `monitor` endpoints

committed 08:14PM - 12 Aug 24 UTC
katherine-signal
+1525 -45

(thanks @kara42 for the catch!)

The EFF has a good summary of what it means:

Electronic Frontier Foundation – 14 Jan 17

Google Launches Key Transparency While a Trade-Off in WhatsApp Is Called a...

The Guardian ran a sensational story on Friday claiming a backdoor was discovered in WhatsApp, enabling intelligence agencies to snoop on encrypted messages. Gizmodo followed up saying it's no backdoor at all, but reasonable, intended behavior. So...

(TL;DR - it’s a good tool, still not as good as verifying safety numbers)

From searching the GitHub org, it seems this is only a thing in the Signal-Server currently. I’m curious to see what the final implementation will look like, and how will it be made clear that comparing Safety Numbers is still the superior way to ensure the encryption is behaving as expected. Maybe change “View Safety Number” to “Verify Encryption”, which still leads you to the same safety number page to begin with, but that also has a button that leads to Key Transparency verification?

link_counts.title: Google Launches Key Transparency While a Trade-Off in WhatsApp Is Called a Backdoor | Electronic Frontier Foundation
Key transparency `search` and `monitor` endpoints · signalapp/Signal-Server@84c329e · GitHub

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
I’m not that good at code, but it seems the key lookup is designed to do multiple keys at once?

github.com

signalapp/Signal-Server/blob/main/service/src/main/java/org/whispersystems/textsecuregcm/controllers/KeyTransparencyController.java#L78-L82


      
    
          
  1. @ApiResponse(responseCode = "200", description = "All search key lookups were successful", useReturnTypeSchema = true)
    2. 
          
  2. @ApiResponse(responseCode = "403", description = "At least one search key lookup to value mapping was invalid")
    3. 
          
  3. @ApiResponse(responseCode = "404", description = "At least one search key lookup did not find the key")
    4. 
          
  4. @ApiResponse(responseCode = "413", description = "Ratelimited")
    5. 
          
  5. @ApiResponse(responseCode = "422", description = "Invalid request format")
    6.
github.com

signalapp/Signal-Server/blob/main/service/src/main/java/org/whispersystems/textsecuregcm/controllers/KeyTransparencyController.java#L138-L141


      
    
          
  1. @ApiResponse(responseCode = "200", description = "All search keys exist in the log", useReturnTypeSchema = true)
    2. 
          
  2. @ApiResponse(responseCode = "404", description = "At least one search key lookup did not find the key")
    3. 
          
  3. @ApiResponse(responseCode = "413", description = "Ratelimited")
    4. 
          
  4. @ApiResponse(responseCode = "422", description = "Invalid request format")
    5.

so maybe it’ll be designed to happen in the background, or happen en-masse upon prompt for the user? I’ll guess we’ll wait and see.

posts.name: kara
posts.cooked:
I’m also very curious about the implementation details
The google key transparency github repo linked in the eff article is archived since 2021 it seems. The actively developed and deployed implementations I know about are whatsapp and apple’s imessage.
There seem to be some differences, apple claims their service provides additional security guarantees compared to whatsapp:

iMessage Contact Key Verification advances the state of the art of Key Transparency deployments by having user devices themselves verify consistency proofs and ensure consistency of the KT system across all user devices for an account. These improvements protect against key directory compromise as well as compromise of the transparency service itself, and can detect split views presented by both services.

link_counts.title: Deploying key transparency at WhatsApp - Engineering at Meta
Blog - Advancing iMessage security: iMessage Contact Key Verification - Apple Security Research

posts.name: anon53652
posts.cooked:
rassilon1963:

The EFF has a good summary of what it means

Fortunately, when I switch phones, I use either Titanium Backup or Swift Backup to restore WhatsApp so the key won’t change at all. Signal restores the key from a backup so there it also does not change.

One of the reasons I would never use an iPhone.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
and as was pointed out to me, McMillion is the author of the IETF proposal for key transparency:

IETF Datatracker

Key Transparency

While there are several established protocols for end-to-end encryption, relatively little attention has been given to securely distributing the end-user public keys for such encryption. As a result, these protocols are often still vulnerable to...

we’re getting some of the big dogs on this project!

link_counts.title: draft-mcmillion-key-transparency-02 - Key Transparency

posts.cooked: what exactly does KT do in an app like Signal? can you explain it in very simple words? what does it change for the end user who uses the app? thank you

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
simplifying quite a bit, it allows for over-the-air verification of safety numbers, without needing to compare in person. it’s quite a bit less secure than doing it the old way, but at the same time quite a bit more secure than not doing anything at all.
this is the default way to verify encryption in WhatsApp nowadays.
And why did Signal decide on this less secure approach?

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked: we don’t know how it will be implemented eventually. maybe it will just verify keys in the background and still mark users as unverified unless you compare safety numbers. to assume they’re abandoning or sidelining the traditional approach when all we know is that we have the beginning of server infrastructure is jumping to conclusions.

posts.name: Derek Morr
posts.cooked: You can still do manual verification. But almost no one does that. So this is a more automated approach. It’s better than nothing. The two approaches aren’t mutually exclusive.

posts.name: kara
posts.cooked:
Here is another (outdated?) ietf draft by McMillion that seems to describe the same design, but the writeup seems to have more of a architecture perspective:

ietf.org

Key Transparency Architecture

This document defines the terminology and interaction patterns involved in the deployment of Key Transparency (KT) in a general secure group messaging infrastructure, and specifies the security properties that the protocol provides. It also...

link_counts.title: Key Transparency Architecture

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked:
Exposes the server to verification by users that the keys are legitimate essentially. If Signal went rogue we could tell and detect who was attacked and when.

This is a pure upgrade realistically speaking and discourages account replacements at the server level.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
Whatnoww:

If Signal went rogue we could tell and detect who was attacked and when.

that is the main selling point, however, there is one caveat which is why KT is inferior to verifying manually:
KT only protects from attacks on users that were registered prior to the server going rogue. if I understand correctly, doing MitM since registration is still possible (though I may be wrong).
I also once read that KT only serves as a way to know an attack happened (and thus minimise its consequences) rather than prevent one wholesale, but I know there’s been some advancements in that field so maybe that’s no longer true.

(I am not a cryptography expert and the info in this post may be wrong)
